I am not sure how to approach this review. I rarely write these anyway, but I find this game to be particularly interesting to discuss.

First of all, it is a great idea, and fun to play.

That said, BlackJack, particularly, became utterly unplayable a few days prior to the writing of this review. Tables could not be joined; people had to leave chips on the table; dealers just disappeared into thin air.

Normally, I would chalk it up to some bugs, but there is a principle of great importance here:

If you put your chips on that table, and that table stops working, I don't care if it is 1 cent or 1 billion of them, you should not lose that money because the game fails.

I am incredibly frustrated by the fact that the game came out of alpha, and this is the result. They can NOT charge money for a broken game in this regard. Every casino game needs to be very secure and stable before they begin asking for our cents.

The game will charge a Steam account for the purchase of chips. How can they charge for the purchase of chips when you are forced by fault of the game to leave chips on the table when it locks up?

I love the concept. I am irritated beyond belief (as are most players in the place lately) with the bugged out, game crushing, problems.

Summary: I wouldn't advise placing a bet until I've interrogated everyone in the room to be sure things are working right at the time you are considering joining a game.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. I'm a big fan of casino games in general. I don't gamble much in real life, but it's nice to be able to have fun with little expense. Unfortunately, this game didn't really fit the bill.  From a social aspect, it's fine. Most of the people are nice. The rest of the game though, is severely lacking.

Poker has the same problem it has anywhere else. It's free. People still make boneheaded calls and go all-in with nothing.  The bigger problem is that the only tournament you can play is with 6 people at one table. You start with $50k which would be fine if the blinds didn't go up extremely fast. It makes trying to play a realistic game of poker virtually impossible, as very soon after starting you're pretty much pot committed once you bet anything.

Blackjack is probably the best part of the game though, especially after the last update, it literally feels like the dealer is getting 20 or 21 every other hand. Still, there is money to be made if you know how to play.

That brings me to the worst part of the game, table machines. Slots, keno, video blackjack and video poker are money suckers with what seems like much lower payout percentages than even Vegas. I literally sat there for 30-45 minutes without a single bonus round. Forget trying to bet anything higher than the minimum because you will soon be out of money.  There are only three types of slot machines which gets old really fast especially when none of them pay.  Keno has a minimum bet of $100 and video blackjack has a minimum of $200. With poor payouts, again you will be out of money quickly.  The game also has war, roulette, big wheel, craps and bingo which are all pretty standard.  Again, especially with war, it seems like the more money bet, the lower percentage of times you're going to win.

You have daily tasks to do, receiving $200 for each of the 6. Unfortunately, most of the time you will be spending more than that to complete the tasks. There are weekly tasks, mostly revolving around getting a certain amount of XP. An example of the problem with this is me spending 45 minutes playing a $400 per spin slot machine, losing 40k and gaining a whopping 200xp. That would have been great if the weekly task wasn't 1,000 XP with a few thousand reward for doing so.  There is a VIP section for high rollers but I honestly don't know how people get to be high rollers unless they have spent real money or gotten extremely lucky.

Again, I really wanted to like the game. Unforunately, there is better poker to be had on any online site and the rest of the game is just no fun with the extremely low payouts.  If you're just in it for the social aspect and don't mind betting small, go for it. Otherwise, I'd stick with other products.

reviewText:
From one of the old 'big dogs' of Playstation Home, Four Kings is a solid casino title, with a lot to offer, but a fair few minor flaws.  I haven't tested every single title, but after spending a chunk of time on several, I can say the following:

Pros:
A good set of titles that all function well; poker is of course only as good as the players you get, but all the basic functionality and pomp is here, combined with the daily tasks and tier increases that made PS Home attractive for folks like me.  It is, in essence, a wide array of gambling options with level ups and leveling bonuses.  That's kind of awesome.

Regular influx of chips.  Playing for free long-term is entirely possible due to getting a decent chunk of chips for free from a number of resources (daily super slots, daily/weekly tasks for more chips, 250 chips every 15 minutes in game), which keeps the title from feeling locked off to any reasonable extent.

Looks great.  Not Skyrim-with-a-million-graphics-mods great, but there's obviously been a lot of work to make the Four Kings look interesting, like the kind of place you could go for a vacation.

Cons
Lack of counter of autoplay.  This is a minor quibble but it does frustrate.  I like to play the machine game 'Instant Keno', and it's a bit annoying that when I select the autoplay option that until it gets to the final play, I have no visual indicator how many runs I have left.

Wasted space.  I love the nightclub and the apartment!  They look great, and again bring me back to what I liked about Playstation Home.  Except, they have no purpose at present.  The nightclub has the same music as the rest of the game.  The DJ booth, the bars, all have no interactivity.  The apartment is arguably worse, in that while it looks lovely, there's no way to interact with anything in this allegedly personal space, not even the televisions that look for all the world like they SHOULD be interactive.  I don't want these spaces excized, mind you; it helps to separate the title from generic casino titles in a similar vein, but all of the above needs SOME measure of interaction.  Mini-games, additional places to spend chips/RP/etc, looping videos, new music, I don't care what.  But for it to be lacking all of that makes it little more than window dressing.

Limited spending options.  At present, chips let you play games, winning gives you RP, which can be used to buy a SMALL handful of avatar items, and if you earn X amount in a single month, you get VIP access for a month.  And... that's it.  Can't upgrade your apartment, avatar options are super limited, no special entertainment options for expending RP, etc, etc.  I hope this changes, as there's a lot of room here for enhancement of the overall experience beyond the casino games (which, again, work great and are decently diverse).


Overall, the game is a recommend.  Yes, it has flaws, and I hope to see the title expand a LOT.  But what is there right now is a complete gambling title with solid gameplay in a good environment with countless options for snagging more chips for free and getting your fix on for the day.  And for an entry price of free, it's hard not to say give it a shot.

I would say the rating system kept me going, but there was no actual pride to be had with it... yeah I'm tier 12 at poker.. what do I get?  Nothing.  Tier 25?  Nothing.  Lets not delude the fact that even if there were a prize, there would be nothing to do with it

In summary, the game is a borefest with a casino skin.  If you like sitting around pretending to play poker and blackjack, then this game might be for you.  But if you are a normal human being who enjoys mental stimulation... Steer clear of this waste of time.
